Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2014 09:13AM sarahsusername wrote: Hi Tracey, I just wanted to let you know that you are definitely not alone in all of this and this is such a wonderful place to find support and see that many are going through the same thing. I don't have breast cancer but my mom was diagnosed a few years ago with mets to her bones (her first diagnosis was 20+ years ago). Since then, they have found spots on her liver and more recently, the areas on her bones and liver have shown growth so they have switched her from hormonal treatment to chemo. It is definitely a heartbreaking ordeal and it is hard seeing someone we love and look up to go through it. I spent some good days crying when I found out the cancer progressed, just because I tend to think of the worst. Thank goodness for this community who help me keep realistic but hopeful outlooks in mind. Never give up hope! It's not over til it's over. There are those who live many years with stage IV, and who's to say that your mom won't be one of them. Just continue to encourage her, I know it will mean so much. Sarah
Posts.Title: So Scared For My Mom Tre4 Tre4

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2014 11:18AM sarahsusername wrote: Incredibly well-written. Thank you thank you thank you!

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2015 11:49AM sarahsusername wrote: And the same to all of you!
Posts.Title: BLESSED EASTER TO ONE AND ALL Teakie88 sarahsusername

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2015 07:28PM sarahsusername wrote: Hi coolcat, thank you so much for sharing your story with me. Family history is serious matter and it sounds like you did an incredibly thorough job and spent a good deal of time thinking over your decisions which is great. Oftentime, especially in a lot of cases dealing with bc, knowledge is power and I know it was not an easy decision but I commend how you've been so proactive. I definitely want to be the same way. I am a bit anxious/excited to meet with this genetic counselor. She is only in a few times a week and there was a bit of delay getting the proper paperwork to her but I am looking forward to getting some real answers (my guesses have run wild) about my true risk. My mom has is in the middle of getting a referral for genetic testing (as i've mentioned, she has texted negative for both BRCA's in the past) and that will give me us more answers, although it would even be great to meet with a counselor for some peace of mind and insight to prepare myself for either kinds of test results. Thanks again for chiming in. All the best and well wishes & a smooth road to recovery!
Posts.Title: Mom & cousin on mom's side, diagnosed at 37 sarahsusername sarahsusername

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2015 07:50PM sarahsusername wrote: Zillsnot4me So glad to hear that it helped with your lungs! I would love for that to happen for my mom. Fingers crossed! Thank you for your sweet words, I wish you the very best as you go through this journey. Even experiencing this in the second degree is hard, I can't imagine how it is for all of your amazing women. It is all pretty frustrating at times, but I am extremely thankful for this forum. xo, Sarah
Posts.Title: Adriamycin, treatment questions for liver, effusions, bone sarahsusername sarahsusername

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2015 11:08PM sarahsusername wrote: nancyh Thank you so much for the well wishes for my mom. Yes, it has definitely been a tough road for her as the liquid accumulating around her lungs has caused frequent and harsh coughing as well as shortness of breath. They haven't done the talc procedure but she has had several thoracenteses in the last six months. She has been having bad side effects from adriamycin so far, the biggest being frequent vomiting. We are praying hard and crossing our fingers that it is killing some cancer cells! Thanks again for chiming in. All the love & best wishes to you! xo, Sarah
Posts.Title: Adriamycin, treatment questions for liver, effusions, bone sarahsusername sarahsusername

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2015 11:31PM sarahsusername wrote: freebird53 Thank you so much Carla! My mom had her first cycle of RD on Thursday so you both are on the path of something you. Just sent a prayer for you and my mom that our new chemos will prove to be successful in shrinking and getting rid of as much cancer as possible! Wouldn't that be great?! Ahh, I've been known to be a pessimistic person but when it comes to this I am forcing myself to see that there's no reason to diminish hope if there is hope and even in the hard days, to still find whatever ray of light we have and be thankful for every day with my mom. Anyway, I am so glad you had a great day & such wise words to make a positive outlook a priority. I forget that sometimes. All the best!
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2015 12:16PM sarahsusername wrote: Thank you so much for your insight farmerlucy vlnrph As you both know, this whole thing has been such a trying experience for my mom and cousin as well as on the hearts of everyone involved. It is so unfortunate that bc can be so sneaky and that even with proven or not-proven mutations, it really has know true rhyme or reason. Even with my mom being diagnosed at 37, her first recurrence came ten years later at 47, she was cleared, and then it came back again at 55, first in the bone, now in the liver & surrounding the lungs. Breast cancer wouldn't leave her alone. She recently started the red devil and we're hoping this is the one to kick cancer's butt. Now it's a matter of getting her tested again, hopefully her insurance can cover a larger spectrum of genes as she has only been tested for the BRCA ones and that was decades ago.
Posts.Title: Mom & cousin on mom's side, diagnosed at 37 sarahsusername sarahsusername

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2015 05:39PM sarahsusername wrote: Thanks vlnrph! Yes, she is a tough woman for sure. I cannot imagine how it must've been to have gotten cancer three times, ughh. Such a sneaky beast. Her symptoms after taking adriamycin have been tough for sure. After the first week the nausea and pain haven't been bad at all. The thing that's been the worst for her is the shortness of breath and coughing, but that's due to the cancer (pleural effusion) so it's a matter of finding a chemo to help with that. After having successes with hormonal therapy for three years ('11-'14), they stopped working and cancer spread last summer and since then she has been on Gemzar, Taxol & Tacotere -- all of which did not help at all. We are praying hard and holding onto hope that Adriamycin is the one to shrink some of these tumors and dry up this effusion so she can finally breathe easy and actually have an uninterrupted night of sleep (it has literally been months since that's happened).
Posts.Title: Mom & cousin on mom's side, diagnosed at 37 sarahsusername sarahsusername

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2015 07:52PM sarahsusername wrote: My mom just started on Adriamycin yesterday after having no luck with Gemzar, Taxotere & Taxol. Praying that this is the drug to help shrink these tumors! Last petscan showed more spots on her liver, bones & she has the bilateral pleural effusion which started a few months ago. Hoping we catch a break! Anyone else have a good experience with the red devil?
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2015 05:14PM sarahsusername wrote: Hi there, My mom has mets in her bones, liver & malignant pleural effusion (fluid around her lungs). Due to the effusion, she hasn't been able to have a petscan since January so a lot of the changes in treatment are gauged by her pain, some nodes near her neck (getting larger or same size, etc) and the fluid reaccumulation in her lungs. It is frustrating (to say the least) that we are unable to have any scans to see what is going on inside her body and to decipher if her symptoms are cancer related or treatment related -- to figure out really if she has gotten better or worse. What's interesting though is with the influx of some pain subsiding and some pain getting stronger in certain areas -- the pain in her liver is gone. There was a time a couple of months ago where it crazy painful for her. Is this a good sign? The bloodwork for liver function has come back good. But since we don't have the scans, I just don't know.. Thanks so much for any and all advice! xo, Sarah
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2015 05:33PM sarahsusername wrote: Oh tanyah, thank you so much for chiming in here and sharing your story. Thank you so much for your kind words and insight from your experience. I am so glad to hear that your mom is cancer free today, but am so sorry for yours and your sister's recent diagnosis. Cancer is synonymous to "the end is near" to the outside world, but as we know, this doesn't have to be the case and I am glad that there are strides to better the treatment and chances for those involved. Sending prayers and well wishes to your family. I totally understand your younger sister's concern. Wow, we really do have a lot in common in that there seems to be a lot of girls in our family and the young diagnosis. I can't imagine what a whirlwind of emotion it must have been for you and your family (with a new nephew too, congrats!) this past year. And speaking of girls, my mom is one of four girls, I have five girl cousins, I have three daughters. I don't know how much all of that downplays in risk and genetics, but I do know that the fact that my mom and my cousin were both 37 during their initial diagnosis, doesn't seem to be good sign.. My gut leans to the fact that there is something in our genes, but to be honest, I tend to be an anxious/glass half full when it comes to chances so either way, it will be good if my mom can get tested with the wider spectrum soon. But like you said, even if she is negative, there are still mutations that have yet to be discovered. It's all such a weary experience. I'm sure that meeting with a genetic counselor to discuss our family's history in detail will provide better information and how I can be proactive now and in the future.
Posts.Title: Mom & cousin on mom's side, diagnosed at 37 sarahsusername sarahsusername

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2015 11:51PM sarahsusername wrote: My mom was diagnosed with bc in 1994, went into remission. It came back in 2004, into remission again. In 2011 it came back in her bones. & for the first three years she did everything she normally did, you could never even tell she was sick. Hormonal therapy kept everything stable with a couple of faint spots near her liver. Unfortunately last summer there was progression on her liver and now she has malignant pleural effusion. The past months have been tough on her (& her family to see) of course, but we are very thankful that she has been given many years from the start. So it's been 21 years since her initial diagnosis, almost 4 years since her Stage IV diagnosis & we are praying + hoping for more. Same to you ladies!
Posts.Title: 15 -20% 5 year survival rate..huh? LeeLee38 JeninMichigan

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2015 11:12PM sarahsusername wrote: Hi there! I am the voice of my mom on this website, she was diagnosed with mets to her bones and small spots near her liver in July '11. She was good on hormonal treatment until September of last year when they showed progression. Since then, the scans have shown more spots on her liver, more spots on her bone, bilateral pleural effusions and most recently this past week, a small pericardial effusion. She has been on Gemzar, no luck with that; then Taxotere, no luck there either & now on Taxol, although from the looks of things, it doesn't seem to be working. Needless to say, it is all pretty discouraging. We are in the process of getting a second opinion for her at a prestigious cancer center in our city that also participates in clinical trial. The hit or miss of finding an effective treatment (hopefully there is one!) is frustrating. Hoping on all hopes that we find a good treatment that will shrink these liver tumors and help these spots on her bones!
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2015 11:52PM sarahsusername wrote: MusicLover Thank you so much for your well wishes and it is definitely an encouragement! Bestbird That is good to know! As always, thank you so much for chiming in. There is so much information her oncologist doesn't give us, I know it's not his job to walk us through every little step - but thank goodness for this site and for you! steelrose Oh my goodness, thank you for sharing your experience! I am going to pass it on to my mom and hopes that it would encourage her in that direction. It is her decision, her body going through all of this so I can understand how hard it is for her day in and day out but how wonderful if she could have the same experience that you did. How amazing that radiation was able to do wonders for you! I love stories like that. Catesmom Thank you for your advice! There aren't many members on with malignant pleural effusion so hearing advice is gold. I will share everything you said with my mom. She has had a thoracentesis almost every week (like you did) and it is definitely a tiring process for her. They are never able to fully drain it either (it starts to get painful) which can be hard because she never feels full relief. That would be amazing if she would be able to get a procedure like that done so she can actually breathe easier and rest easier. Yes, they recently put her on oxygen this past month to help her. // thank you all so much for your advice & encouragement! Hoping that time proves this treatment is effective & that we will get some clear answers. xo, Sarah
